Does anyone have any good anecdotes of B.W. Robinson?  I am planning to put up an obituary on my blog.  I have a couple of photos, which are not terribly good, so a better photo would be helpful as well.

David Zincavage
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: John Berta 
  To: token_kenkyu_kai@... 
  Sent: Tuesday, January 03, 2006 3:41 PM
  Subject: Re: B.W.Robinson


  Very sad news.  The very first book I ever found in English on Japanese swords was written by him.

  The Japanese sword community has lost a leader.

  John
    ----- Original Message ----- 
    From: Malcolm Cox 
    To: token_kenkyu_kai@... 
    Sent: Tuesday, January 03, 2006 4:45 AM
    Subject: Re: B.W.Robinson


    Thank you for the report.  Mr Robinson and his publications were a highly valuable source of pre-electronic information on Nihonto.  He is much admired and highly respected, and was indeed a real scholar.  Sincere condolences to his family and colleagues.
    Malcolm Cox


    At 10:22 PM 3/01/2006, you wrote:

      I am sorry to have to report the death of Basil Robinson on December 29, he was 93. In the early 60s I took blades to the V&A museum to be vetted and he was always unfailingly polite about the most outrageous rubbish that I showed him, also I think most collectors of my age were started on the slippery slope of sword collecting by his 'Arts of the Japanese Sword'.
      Alan

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
